contentrichtext.text: {{ infobox nobility | name = Hugh III of Burgundy | image = Hugh III.jpg | caption = Seal of Hugh III of Burgundy | noble family = [[House of Burgundy]] | father = [[Odo II, Duke of Burgundy]] | mother = Marie of Champagne | spouse = Alice of Lorraine<br/>[[Béatrice of Albon]] | birth_date = 1142 | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date|1192|8|25|df=y}} | death_place = [[Acre, Israel|Acre]] }} '''Hugh III of Burgundy''' (1142 – August 25, 1192) was [[duke of Burgundy]] between 1162 and 1192. Hugh was the eldest son of duke [[Odo II, Duke of Burgundy|Odo II]] and Marie of Champagne, daughter of [[Theobald II, Count of Champagne|Theobald]] and Mathilda of Carinthia. The rule of Hugh III marked the ending of a period of relative peace in the duchy of Burgundy. Hugh was a belligerent man and soon was involved in conflicts against king [[Louis VII of France]] over their borders. When [[Philip II of France|Philip Augustus]] succeeded Louis in 1180, Hugh seized the opportunity and forced several men to change alliance to Burgundy. Philip II was not happy with the loss of his vassals and invaded the duchy, besieging Châtillon. The town fell and with it, its garrison, commanded by Eudes, Hugh's heir. A peace was negotiated and Hugh had to pay a high ransom for his son and give up ambitions over French territory. Hugh then turned his energies to the Holy Land, embarking in the [[Third Crusade]] in the retinue of Philip II. He was the most trusted ally of [[Richard I of England|Richard, the Lionheart]] and fought with him against [[Saladin]]. When Philip returned to France, he left Hugh in charge of the French troops. Hugh played a major role in the victory of the [[battle of Arsuf]] (September 7, 1191) and the conquest of [[Acre, Israel|Acre]], where he died in the following year. In 1187, Hugh transferred the capital of Burgundy to [[Dijon]], and endeavoured to turn the city into a major commercial centre. ==Marriage and issue== He was married twice: * Firstly, in 1165, to Alice of Lorraine (1145–1200), daughter of [[Matthias I, Duke of Lorraine]]; he repudiated her in 1183. * Secondly, in 1183, to [[Béatrice of Albon]] (1161–1228), [[Count of Albon|Countess of Albon and Dauphine of Viennois]], daughter of [[Guigues V of Albon|Guigues, Count of Albon and Dauphin of Viennois]]. By his first marriage, he produced: * [[Odo III, Duke of Burgundy|Odo III]] (1166–1218), his successor in the Duchy *Alexander (1170–1205), Lord of Montagu, founder of the line of Seigneurs of [[Montagu]] *Douce (1175 – c.1219), married in 1196 Simon [[Brionnais|of Semur]] (d.1219), Lord of Luzy *Alix (b.1177), married Béraud VII, Lord of Mercœur By his second marriage, he produced: * [[Guy VI of Viennois|Guy VI]] (1184–1237), Dauphin of Viennois * Mahaut (1190–1242), married in 1214 [[John I, Count of Chalon or Châlon|John I, Count of Châlon and Auxonne]] (1190–1267) * [[Anne of Burgundy, Countess of Savoy|Anne]] (1192–1243), married in 1222 [[Amadeus IV of Savoy|Amadeus IV]] (1197–1253), [[Count of Savoy]] ==See also== * [[Dukes of Burgundy family tree]] {{s-start}} {{s-hou|[[House of Burgundy]]||1142|25 August|1192}} {{succession box|title=[[Duke of Burgundy]]|before=[[Odo II, Duke of Burgundy|Odo II]]|after=[[Odo III, Duke of Burgundy|Odo III]]|years=1162–1192}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Hugh III of Burgundy | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Hugues III de Bourgogne (French) | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Duke of Burgundy (1162-1192) | DATE OF BIRTH = 1142 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = August 25, 1192 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Acre, Israel|Acre]] }} [[Category:1142 births]] [[Category:1192 deaths]] [[Category:House of Burgundy]] [[Category:Dukes of Burgundy]] [[Category:Christians of the Third Crusade]]
